sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Community acquired pneumonia: 600 mg IV (over 1 hour) every 12 hours for 5 to 7 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Acute): 600 mg IV infusion over 1 hour every 12 hours for 5 to 14 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in children

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment (CrCl, greater than 30 to 50 mL/min): 400 mg IV (over 1 hour) every 12 hours
  • renal impairment (CrCl, 15 to 30 mL/min): 300 mg IV (over 1 hour) every 12 hours
  • ESRD (CrCl, less than 15 mL/min) or hemodialysis: 200 mg IV (over 1 hour) every 12 hours; administer after hemodialysis on hemodialysis days

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Community acquired pneumonia
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Acute)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to ceftaroline or other cephalosporins

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylaxis and anaphylactoid reactions, serious and occasionally fatal, have been reported
  • hypersensitivity to penicillins or other beta-lactams, history; potential for cross-hypersensitivity
  • renal impairment (moderate to end-stage); risk of toxicity; dosage adjustment required
  • report suspected adverse reactions to Forest Pharmaceuticals, Inc. at 1-800-678-1605 or to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash (3%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (5%), Nausea (4%)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile colitis (less than 2%)
  • Hepatic:Hepatitis (less than 2%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (less than 2%)
  • Neurologic:Seizure (less than 2%)
  • Renal:Renal failure (less than 2%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ceftaroline is a cephalosporin active against Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria; ceftaroline binds to essential penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), and is active against providing Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pneumoniae due to affinity for PBP2a and PBP2x, respectively.

sub.mono:

  • Ceftaroline (active drug), Protein binding: 20%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:

  • Ceftaroline: active

sub.mono:

  • Renal: 88%
  • Ceftaroline (active drug), Renal: 64%
  • Ceftaroline (active drug), Renal clearance: 5.56 L/hr
  • Ceftaroline fosamil (prodrug), Dialyzable: Yes (hemodialysis)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • reconstitute individual 400-mg or 600-mg vial with 20 mL of sterile water for injection, NS, D5W, or LR
  • (dilution in infusion bags greater than 50 mL) further dilute reconstituted vial in up to 250 mL of same solution used for reconstitution, unless sterile water for injection was used; if reconstituted with sterile water for injection, use NS, 0.45% NS, D5W, 2.5% dextrose injection,, or LR
  • (dilution in 50 mL infusion bags) withdraw 20 mL of diluent from infusion bag, then add total volume of reconstituted vial for a final volume of 50 mL
  • do not mix or add to solutions containing other drugs
  • use the constituted solution in the infusion bag within 6 hours when stored at room temperature or within 24 hours when refrigerated at 2 to 8 degrees C (36 to 46 degrees F)
  • infuse IV over approximately 1 hour

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• CBC, culture and susceptibility tests during treatment to assess therapeutic response
  • signs and symptoms of bacterial infection; improvement is indicative of efficacy
  • anemia, during and after treatment; if occurs, perform diagnostic studies (including a direct Coombs' test)
  • renal function in elderly patients

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
OVERDOSE: Acute ingestion of large doses of cephalosporins may result in nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Seizures have developed after parenteral overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, may commonly occur with therapy; oral exposures are less likely to cause severe allergic reactions than parenteral exposures. Seizures have also been reported following therapeutic administration. Prolonged prothrombin times, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathies associated with a qualitative platelet defect and aggregation abnormalities have been reported following IV cephalosporin therapy. Pseudocholelithiasis may follow intravenous administration of ceftriaxone. Several cases of fatal hemolytic reactions following intravenous ceftriaxone therapy have been reported in children with serious hematologic abnormalities.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
  • Decontamination: Generally not indicated in patients with no underlying health problems. Activated charcoal may be necessary for patients with underlying renal insufficiency.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor renal function, electrolytes, CBC including platelets.
  • Anaphylaxis: Mild to moderate allergic reactions may be treated with antihistamines with or without inhaled beta adrenergic agonists, corticosteroids or epinephrine. Diphenhydramine: ADULTS: 50 mg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 25 to 50 mg orally every 4 to 6 hours for 24 to 72 hours. CHILDREN: 1.25 mg/kg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 5 mg/kg/day orally in 4 divided doses for 24 to 72 hours. Treatment of severe anaphylaxis also includes oxygen supplementation, aggressive airway management, epinephrine, ECG monitoring, and IV fluids.
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Blood coagulation disorder: Vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma
  • Intrathecal injection: Treat seizures with anticonvulsants (benzodiazepines, propofol, phenobarbital); endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation as needed. Keep the patient upright if possible. Immediately drain at least 20 mL CSF; drainage of up to 70 mL has been tolerated in adults. Follow with CSF exchange (remove serial 20 mL aliquots CSF and replace with equivalent volumes of warmed, preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers). For large overdoses, consult a neurosurgeon for placement of a ventricular catheter and begin ventriculolumbar perfusion (infuse warmed preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers through ventricular catheter, drain fluid from lumbar catheter; typical volumes 80 to 150 mL/hr). Dexamethasone 4 mg intravenously every 6 hours to prevent arachnoiditis.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
TOXICITY: Serious toxicity is unlikely following large oral doses of cephalosporins. Crystalluria and hematuria has been described in a 3-year-old boy who ingested 104 mg/kg of cephalexin. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies with agent. CEPHALEXIN: CHILDREN: 25 to 100 milligrams/kilogram/24 hours orally, up to a maximum of 4 grams/day, divided every 6 hours.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause diarrhea, nausea, and rash.
  • Advise patient to immediately report severe watery or bloody diarrhea and consult a healthcare professional prior to taking antidiarrheal medication.
